instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message:
With new keyboard/trackpad/trackpad cable same story.

Keyboard connector:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.32V

Trackpad connector:
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4_TPAD_FUSE</SIGNAL> = 13V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL> = 3.32V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message: Is the trackpad/keyboard listed in OSX under USB devices?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message: no, they are not listed there

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message:
Sorry, this one will be listed under SPI devices, can you check again? Was this liquid damage?
Also check if it works when you are in the boot menu, hold down ALT key when turning on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message:
No Title

No problem Duke.
No devices under SPI.
ALT not works during boot (on ext USB keyboard works fine)
There is just one small liquid marks like on photo bellow (no other signs of liquid).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message: Have you taken the board out and inspected everything, trackpad connector first of course. Does the trackpad click when powered on? These force touch ones don't click without power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message:
Yes, I removed board and checked the other side and rest looks good.

There is a click on trackpad (single, not double as normal force touch).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard, no trackpad
threads.message: So there is no click when off and there is a click when on? Have you swapped a known good trackpad and cable together?
